definitions.definition: to stop or hesitate as if suddenly seeing a bogle .
examples: The dogs went on, but the horse boggled at the sudden appearance of the strange beast.
The horror of the deed and its consequences boggle the imagination.

definitions.definition: To be bewildered , dumbfounded , or confused .
examples: He boggled at the surprising news.
The vastness of space really boggles the mind.
The oddities of quantum mechanics can boggle the minds of students and experienced physicists alike.

definitions.definition: To embarrass with difficulties ; to palter or equivocate ; to bungle or botch
To dissemble ; to play fast and loose ( with someone or something).
To wiggle the eyes as a result of bruxing .

main_definition: ( transitive or intransitive ) ( literally or figuratively ) to stop or hesitate as if suddenly seeing a bogle .
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive ) To be bewildered , dumbfounded , or confused .
( transitive ) To confuse or mystify ; overwhelm .
( US , dialect ) To embarrass with difficulties ; to palter or equivocate ; to bungle or botch
( intransitive , obsolete ) To dissemble ; to play fast and loose ( with someone or something).
( intransitive , of a rat ) To wiggle the eyes as a result of bruxing .
